support_summary: ATG4B is a cysteine protease that processes the pro-LC3B form to its active LC3B-I form by cleaving the C-terminus. It also de-lipidates LC3B-II from the autophagosome membrane. This is a direct enzyme-substrate interaction and ATG4B contains a LIR motif.

functions.cellular_process: ATG4B is a cysteine protease that performs the initial and essential maturation step of newly synthesized pro-LC3B. It cleaves off a short C-terminal peptide to expose a glycine residue (Gly120).
functions.effect_description: This cleavage converts the inactive pro-LC3B into the cytosolic, soluble form LC3B-I. Exposing the C-terminal glycine is an absolute requirement for LC3B-I to be recognized and activated by the E1-like enzyme ATG7, thereby priming it for its role in autophagy.
biological_consequence: Binding of pro-LC3B to ATG4B active site → Proteolytic cleavage of C-terminal residues → Exposure of Glycine 120 → Generation of cytosolic LC3B-I → Availability for ATG7-mediated activation
specific_effects: Cleaves the C-terminal residues of pro-LC3B to expose a terminal glycine.
This priming step is essential for subsequent recognition by ATG7 and lipidation.
ATG4B possesses the highest catalytic efficiency for this cleavage among the four human ATG4 homologs.

evidence.paper_title: LC3B Binds to the Autophagy Protease ATG4b with High Affinity Using a Bipartite Interface
evidence.relevant_quote: The cysteine protease ATG4b acts at two stages in the life cycle of LC3B... Human pro-LC3B contains 125 residues comprised of a ubiquitin-like core and a C-terminal tail. ATG4b cleaves the last 5 residues of pro-LC3B to expose Gly120 for further lipidation.

evidence.paper_title: The structure of Atg4B–LC3 complex reveals the mechanism of LC3 processing and delipidation during autophagy
evidence.relevant_quote: Regulation of PE conjugation and deconjugation of Atg8 is crucial for these functions in which Atg4 has a critical function by both processing Atg8 precursors and deconjugating Atg8–PE.

functions.cellular_process: ATG4B also acts as a deconjugating enzyme, reversing the lipidation process. It cleaves the amide bond between LC3B-II and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) on autophagosomal membranes.
functions.effect_description: This delipidation activity releases LC3B from the membrane, recycling it back into the cytosolic pool of LC3B-I. This recycling is crucial for maintaining a supply of LC3B for sustained autophagic flux and is also involved in regulating the size and maturation of the autophagosome.
biological_consequence: Recognition of membrane-bound LC3B-II by ATG4B → Cleavage of the LC3B-PE amide bond → Release of LC3B-I into the cytosol → Maintenance of the cytosolic LC3B-I pool for reuse → Regulation of autophagosome maturation
specific_effects: Catalyzes the deconjugation of LC3B-II from PE, reversing the lipidation step.
Recycles LC3B, making it available for subsequent rounds of autophagosome formation.
The delipidation activity of ATG4B can be regulated by post-translational modifications, such as phosphorylation, which increases its activity.

evidence.paper_title: An Atg4B Mutant Hampers the Lipidation of LC3 Paralogues and Causes Defects in Autophagosome Closure
evidence.relevant_quote: The LC3 lipidation process is reversible, because the Atg4 proteases can also catalyze the reverse modification reaction, termed delipidation, of LC3/Atg8.

evidence.paper_title: Suppression of ATG4B by copper inhibits autophagy and involves in Mallory body formation
evidence.relevant_quote: ATG4B could execute two LC3 proteolytic processing events: priming of pro-LC3 to LC3-I and deconjugation of LC3-II to LC3-I.

evidence.paper_title: Delipidation of mammalian Atg8-family proteins by each of the four ATG4 proteases
evidence.relevant_quote: The ATG4 family of proteases drives both cleavages, but how ATG4 proteins distinguish between soluble and lipid-anchored Atg8 proteins is not well understood.

mechanism: ATG4B is a cysteine protease that performs the initial and essential maturation step of newly synthesized pro-LC3B. It cleaves off a short C-terminal peptide to expose a glycine residue (Gly120). ATG4B also acts as a deconjugating enzyme, reversing the lipidation process. It cleaves the amide bond between LC3B-II and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) on autophagosomal membranes.
effect: This cleavage converts the inactive pro-LC3B into the cytosolic, soluble form LC3B-I. Exposing the C-terminal glycine is an absolute requirement for LC3B-I to be recognized and activated by the E1-like enzyme ATG7, thereby priming it for its role in autophagy.; This delipidation activity releases LC3B from the membrane, recycling it back into the cytosolic pool of LC3B-I. This recycling is crucial for maintaining a supply of LC3B for sustained autophagic flux and is also involved in regulating the size and maturation of the autophagosome.
summary: LC3B activates ATG4B to regulate pro-lc3b proteolytic cleavage and lc3b-ii delipidation and recycling, ultimately affecting availability for atg7-mediated activation.
